caption: Figure 1: Illustration of flow matching methods on the 2-Wasserstein manifold, P2(X), depicted as a two-dimensional sphere. Flow Matching learns the tangent vectors to a single curve on the manifold. Conditional generation corresponds to learning a finite set of curves on the manifold, e.g. classes c1 and c2 on the plot. Meta Flow Matching learns to integrate a vector field on P2(X), i.e. for every starting density po Meta Flow Matching defines a push-forward measure that integrates along the underlying vector field.
description: This figure illustrates the core concepts of Flow Matching, Conditional Flow Matching, and Meta Flow Matching using the 2-Wasserstein manifold visualized as a sphere. Flow Matching focuses on a single curve, representing the evolution of a single population. Conditional Flow Matching extends this to multiple curves representing different conditions. Meta Flow Matching goes further by learning a vector field, allowing for generalization to unseen initial distributions.

caption: Figure 4: Model-generated samples for synthetic letters from the source (t = 0) to target (t = 1) distributions.
description: This figure shows the results of a synthetic experiment on denoising letters.  Three models are compared: Flow Matching (FM), Conditional Flow Matching (CGFM), and Meta Flow Matching (MFM). For each model, the figure displays samples from the source distribution (t=0), intermediate distributions at t=0.5 and t=1, and the target distribution (t=1). The samples are generated for both seen (train) and unseen (test) letter orientations.  This demonstrates MFM's ability to generalize to unseen data, unlike FM and CGFM.

caption: Figure 3: Organoid drug-screen dataset overview. Left: a given replica consists of a control distribution p0 and corresponding treatment response distribution p1 for treatment condition ci. Right: train and test data splits for replica (top) and patients (bottom) splits, restively. For each experiment there are 11 treatments, 10 patients and 3 culture conditions.
description: This figure illustrates the organoid drug-screen dataset used in the paper.  The left panel shows how a single replica is composed of a control distribution (p0) and a treatment response distribution (p1) for a given treatment condition (ci).  The right panel details the data split strategy used for both replica and patient splits.  The experiment involves 11 different treatments applied to cells from 10 patients under 3 culture conditions (Fibroblasts, PDO, PDOF).

caption: Figure 2: Examples of model-generated samples for synthetic letters from the source distribution (t = 0) to predicted target distribution (t = 1). See Fig. 4 in Appendix F for a larger set of examples.
description: This figure shows examples of synthetic letter generation using three different methods: Flow Matching (FM), Conditional Flow Matching (CGFM), and Meta Flow Matching (MFM).  For each method, the figure displays a sequence of letter generation steps from an initial, noisy source distribution (t=0) to a cleaner target distribution (t=1).  The purpose is to visually demonstrate the ability of each method to denoise and generate letters, with a focus on how MFM handles unseen letter orientations.
